docs.lead_paragraph: The largest health care provider in New York City opened its new headquarters yesterday in Lower Manhattan, representing the biggest corporate relocation to the area since the Sept. 11 attack and signaling a vote of confidence in downtown's ability to bounce back. By opening the office space at 55 Water Street, HIP Health Plan of New York will bring 500 new jobs and relocate 2,000 existing jobs to the area, Gov. George E. Pataki said during a ribbon-cutting ceremony at the headquarters. The company received about $10.8 million in city and state funds to return to Lower Manhattan.

headline.main: HIP's Return Is Seen as Boost For Downtown

docs.abstract: HIP Health Plan of New York opens new headquarters in Lower Manhattan (NYC), bringing 500 new jobs and relocating 2,000 existing jobs to area; move is economic boost to area crippled by Sept 11 terrorist attacks (M)
docs.snippet: HIP Health Plan of New York has opened its new headquarters in Lower Manhattan, becoming the biggest corporation to relocate to the area since the Sept. 11 attacks.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: HIP HEALTH PLAN OF NEW YORK

docs.lead_paragraph: On the campaign trail, President Bush and Senator John Kerry like to highlight elements of their ambitious domestic agendas. But in the last presidential debate, on Wednesday, they are unlikely to dwell on the cost of their own proposals, which budget analysts and tax experts put at roughly $1.3 trillion each over 10 years. Under Mr. Bush's proposals, tax cuts account for an overwhelming share of the costs, whereas under Mr. Kerry's proposals, new spending, mainly for health care and education, accounts for about 60 percent of the additional cost.

headline.main: 2 Rivals Push Domestic Plans, But Say Little of Big Price Tag

docs.abstract: Pres Bush and Sen John Kerry, who both like to highlight elements of their ambitious domestic agendas, are unlikely to dwell in final presidential debate on costs of their proposals, estimated by experts at some $1.3 trillion each over 10 years; tax cuts account for overwhelming share of costs under Bush's proposals; new spending accounts for about 60 percent of added cost of Kerry's proposals; Concord Coalition analysis shows Bush would cut taxes by $1.2 trillion in decade, while Kerry would cut taxes by $498 billion; holds new spending Kerry proposes would total $771 billion, dwarfing $82 billion Bush proposes; estimates Kerry's proposal to repeal tax cuts for 'wealthiest Americans' would raise $278 billion, while his proposal to modify estate tax would generate $8 billion; says Kerry's proposed tax cuts would total $784 billion; most expensive item in Bush's platform, $1 trillion, is his call to extend tax cuts enacted in 2001 and 2003; table of proposals and costs (M)
docs.snippet: In the last presidential debate, the candidates are unlikely to dwell on the cost of their own proposals, which analysts put at roughly $1.3 trillion each over 10 years.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush unleashed a new assault on Senator John Kerry's health care proposals on Tuesday, signaling one of his main lines of attack when the two candidates spar over economic and domestic policy in their third and final debate on Wednesday night. In a speeches here and in Colorado, Mr. Bush suggested that Mr. Kerry's plan to expand access to health care for many of the 45 million people who do not have insurance would put health decisions in the hands of the federal bureaucracy.

headline.main: Bush Campaign Unleashes a New Assault on Kerry's Health Care Proposals

docs.abstract: Pres Bush, in new assault on Sen John Kerry's health care proposals, holds Kerry's plan to expand access to health care for many of 45 million people who lack health insurance would put health decisions in hands of federal bureaucracy, speeches, Phoenix and Colorado; his campaign unveils two commercials attacking plan; Kerry campaign disputes Bush stand and unveils own advertising on health care; scores administration's health policies; cites Bush's unwillingness so far to allow importation of lower-cost prescription drugs from Canada; photo (M)
docs.snippet: John Kerry's health care proposals will probably be one of President Bush's main lines of attack when the two candidates spar over economic and domestic policy on Wednesday.

byline.original: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON; Randal C. Archibold contributed reporting from Commerce City, Colo., for this article and David M. Halb-finger from Santa Fe, N.M

docs.lead_paragraph: Ernestina Miranda left Mexico for the United States in 1979 in the trunk of a car. She found a job sewing blue jeans in one of the dozens of clothing factories here. Work was steady, six days a week, 12 hours a day. She married and bought a trailer -- without running water or electricity -- on a plot of land. She was awarded citizenship in the late 1980's.
docs.abstract: Over 17,000 garment manufacturing jobs have left United States for Mexico and China in 11 years since North American Free Trade Agreement was ratified, threatening livelihoods of Mexicans who were lured to US in 1960's, 70's and 80's by prospect of working in garment factories that moved from Northern states in search of cut-rate border labor; people who have lost jobs, most of them now citizens, are typically illiterate and speak little English; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Mostpeople who have lost their jobs in the garment industry are first-generation Mexican women.

docs.lead_paragraph: Christopher Reeve, the cinematic Superman who became a real-life inspiration through his painstaking efforts to overcome total paralysis, while speaking out for stem-cell research and other potential treatments, died on Sunday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 52 and lived in Pound Ridge, N.Y. Mr. Reeve was being treated for a pressure wound, a common complication for people in wheelchairs, said his publicity agent, Wesley Combs. These wounds result from constant pressure in one spot, reducing the blood to that area and finally killing the affected tissue.

headline.main: Christopher Reeve, 52, Symbol of Courage, Dies

docs.abstract: Christopher Reeve, movie Superman who became real-life hero through his painstaking efforts to overcome total paralysis, speaking out for stem-cell research and other potential treatments, dies at age of 52; after horse riding accident in 1995 left him paralyzed from neck down, he became powerful proponent of causes ranging from insurance reform for catastrophic injuries to unleashing possibilities some scientists believe lie in using embryonic stem cells for research; days before his death, during second presidential debate, Sen John Kerry mentioned him by name in arguing against Pres Bush's position that stem-cell reserch must be restricted to protect lives of human embryos; Reeve's life, his movie career and his advocacy for handicapped recalled; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Christopher Reeve, the cinematic Superman who became a real-life inspiration through his painstaking efforts to overcome total paralysis, while speaking out for stem-cell research and other potential treatments, died on Sunday at Northern Westchester...

docs.lead_paragraph: It's not hard to predict what President Bush, who sounds increasingly desperate, will say tomorrow. Here are eight lies or distortions you'll hear, and the truth about each: Jobs -- Mr. Bush will talk about the 1.7 million jobs created since the summer of 2003, and will say that the economy is ''strong and getting stronger.'' That's like boasting about getting a D on your final exam, when you flunked the midterm and needed at least a C to pass the course.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column predicts eight lies or distortions Pres Bush will utter about his domestic policies during third presidential debate, and truth about each; says Bush's statements on campaign trail are fundamentally dishonest; says Sen John Kerry can be accused of using loose language, but thrust of his statements is correct; says journalists who play it safe by spending equal time exposing Bush's lies and parsing Kerry's choice of words are betraying their readers (M)
docs.snippet: Here are seven lies or distortions you'll hear from the president in the next debate, and the truth about each.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Emily Martin was hospitalized for emergency gallbladder surgery last summer, her doctors found that she also had acid reflux, causing erosion of her esophagus. ''My stomach was very unsettled,'' said Ms. Martin, a 26-year-old mother in Oradell, N.J. So she asked her doctor for Nexium, the ''purple pill'' that is the nation's most widely advertised prescription drug. ''I saw the commercial and they showed people talking about immediate and miracle relief,'' she said.

headline.main: Selling Prescription Drugs to the Consumer

docs.abstract: Issue of drug advertising directly aimed at consumers was thrust into news recently when Merck withdrew its arthritis painkiller Vioxx from market, citing studies indicating risk of heart attacks or strokes; critics noted role that advertising and marketing played in drug's being widely prescribed to patients who might have done as well with ibuprofen or other inexpensive over-the-counter remedies; prescription drug advertising has grown into $3.8-billion-a-year business in seven years since FDA lifted strictures against such ads; FDA has no plans to place new curbs on such ads despite controversy accompanying withdrawal of Vioxx; vice presidential candidate Sen John Edwards during debate last week said drug ads on TV are out of control and that he and Sen John Kerry would do something about ads if elected; Megan Houk, deputy policy director for Bush-Cheney campaign, accuse Democratic candidates of exaggerating issue; charts; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Intensive marketing has helped create blockbuster drugs that aren't necessarily more effective than cheaper alternatives.

byline.original: By STUART ELLIOTT and NAT IVES; Milt Freudenheim contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: When he signed it into law, President Bush hailed the Medicare Modernization Act of 2003 as ''the greatest advance in health care coverage for America's seniors since the founding of Medicare.'' The overhaul of the program, including the addition of prescription drug benefits, was seen as his biggest accomplishment in domestic policy and a major asset to his re-election campaign. But over the last 10 months, the Bush administration's efforts to carry out the first phase of that law, providing drug discount cards to the elderly, have been plagued with difficulties. Many health policy experts say that even greater problems loom as the government turns to the more ambitious task of providing a full-fledged drug benefit to 41 million elderly and disabled people in 2006.

headline.main: Partisan Arguing and Fine Print Seen as Hindering Medicare Law

docs.abstract: Medicare issue, notably success or failure of Pres Bush's Medicare Modernization Act, is expected to be major part of final presidential debate; Bush hails act as 'greatest advance in health care coverage for America's seniors,' but efforts to carry out first phase of law, providing drug discount cards to elderly, have been plagued with difficulties; experts and advocates point to two broad problems: program's emphasis on private market forces and consumer choice, which has made it too complicated for many elderly beneficiaries; Bush administration argues that start-up problems should be expected in any undertaking this big; many health policy experts say even greater problems loom as government turns to more ambitous task of providing full-fledged drug benefit to 41 million elderly and disabled people in 2006; Medicare issue is at center of poisonous partisan debate, intensified by lingering bitterness over cost estimates used to justify law's passage; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Bush administration's efforts to carryout the first phase of the law have been plagued with difficulties.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and ROBIN TONER

docs.lead_paragraph: Her bus was coming, but Charlotte Marshall had not yet finished talking about what mattered to her in the election. Social Security and health insurance, definitely. The Vietnam War, absolutely not. And she had still more to say. The campaign for president has entered its final leg crackling with rare energy on the streets, in workplaces and in homes, perhaps with no greater vigor than among black Americans like Mrs. Marshall, who works for Stein Mart, a discount store.

headline.main: Among Black Voters, a Fervor To Make Their Ballots Count

docs.abstract: Many African-Americans around nation, but especially in Florida--galvanized by memory of 2000 election--are determined to have their votes count this time; African-Americans are part of torrent of new voter registrations in swing states like Florida, Pennsylvania, Ohio and elsewhere; black voter participation has been increasing in recent presidential elections; in 2000, 57 percent of eligible black voters turned out, casting one vote for Pres Bush for every nine cast for Al Gore; over last 15 years, rising black middle class has dispersed from cities into integrated suburbs, creating demand for political messages that reflect diverse circumstances of African-Americans; blacks in Florida, mindful of how many black votes were disqualified in 2000, get pledge from Sen John Kerry that he will fight 'until the last dog dies' in event of another contested voting result; photos (M)
docs.snippet: After the controversy of the 2000 election, many African-Americans are speaking about voting this year with rekindled fervor.

docs.lead_paragraph: If there was any doubt that Senator John Edwards is trying to raise his profile in the final weeks of the campaign, it should have been put to rest Sunday when he appeared on five news and political talk shows. His television blitz followed appearances last week on the ABC morning talk shows ''Regis and Kelly'' and ''The View.'' And on Tuesday, on the eve of the final presidential debate, he is a scheduled guest on NBC's ''Tonight'' show.

headline.main: Edwards Raising His Profile As TV Appearances Increase
headline.kicker: THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATIC RUNNING MATE

docs.abstract: Sen John Edwards seeks to raise his profile in final weeks of presidential campaign; he appears on five Sunday news and political talk shows in single day; this follows weeks of heavy campaigning in rural areas and small-to medium-size cities, trips that earned Sen Kerry campaign presence in local media markets but also drew questions from some Democrats about why Edwards was not more visible nationally; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Any doubt that Senator John Edwards has been trying to raise his profile in the final weeks of the campaign was put to rest with his appearances on news shows.
